Glycerol carbonate (GlyC) is desirable compound among numerous value-added products produced from surplus waste glycerol coming from biodiesel industry. Because of its excellent characteristics properties, applications and high cost, it can contribute to economize the biodiesel production cost. In this work, the research on the impact of support on the catalytic activity towards the synthesis of GlyC have been developed. For this purpose, co-precipitation was used to create Mg and transition metals like Cu and Mn based catalysts, which were then used in the transesterification of glycerol (Gly). Comparative research on the catalytic abilities of MgMn2O4 (MMO) and MgCu4O5 (CMO) were conducted. Among CMO and MMO catalysts, MMO achieved the maximum glycerol conversion of 97%, with 94% GlyC yield, while CMO only offered 83% glycerol conversion with 71% GlyC yield. The 4:1 DMC to Gly molar ratio, 90°C reaction temperature, 75 min reaction time, and 5% catalyst loading were the optimal reaction parameters that were most effective for the synthesis of GlyC utilizing MMO catalyst. MMO was more effective than CMO at synthesizing GlyC because it has a strong basic site. With stability through the sixth cycle, the catalyst has a great potential. An industrial application of the catalyst for large scale is possible. The impact of support transition metal on catalytic activity is established by this study. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Glycerol valorization Heterogeneous catalysts Transesterification Glycerol carbonate Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The need for energy is continuously rising due to the tremendous population growth and technological advancement occurring globally. The biodiesel industry has grown significantly in recent years in response to the current energy demand. A surplus of crude glycerol (about 10% of the overall output) is produced during the manufacturing of biodiesel (BioD) as a substitute for fossil fuels [1]. The excess glycerol mostly hurts the biodiesel companies' ability to compete on the market. Taking into account the financial viability of biodiesel production as well as the surplus glycerol produced from biodiesel industry, there is a need to look upon the new application of the by-product glycerol [2]. Because of all of these concerns, recent research has been focused on the efficient and sustainable conversion of crude Gly into a range of value - added products. The far more promising uses includes the chemical production as a low-cost, renewable raw material to make high-value-added chemical species and polymers [3]. GlyC is the most desirable Gly derivatives due to its exceptional physicochemical qualities. GlyC has the potential to be a greener platform chemical in place of petrochemical compounds such as ethylene carbonate or propylene carbonate. Moreover, it is a solvent that can be used in the paint, battery, and detergent industries [4]. In addition, it can be used to produce high-value intermediates like glycidol, which is used in the production of textile, plastic, pharmaceutical, and cosmetic products. Glycerol carbonate is a substance that has the potential to be commercially successful due to its green and varied future. Glycerol carbonate is regarded as a modest volume chemical with new uses among the compounds made from glycerol. It has a wide range of uses and is a platform chemical [5]. Commercial and industrial relevance pertains to the value addition of Gly since it is non-toxic, edible, renewable, and biodegradable that can be produced in huge quantities. In this way, activating and using glycerol through optimal reaction-catalysis offers a tenable route to green chemical technology [6]. Catalyst development has been worked extensively for a considerable time and is still being researched on. In order to create glycerol carbonate, a number of direct and indirect carbonylating reagents are used, such as phosgene, oxygenatated carbon monoxide, CO2, urea as a source of CO, and transesterification with cyclic/acyclic carbonates. Methanol, which has a low boiling point and can easily get separated from the reaction matrix, is the only by-product produced by the cyclic and acyclic carbonates. The most efficient and long-lasting approach is transesterification with DMC [7]. Several homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, including acid, basic, and acid-base (bifunctional) catalysts, have been developed for all of the methods. Because of their potential for reusability, ease of recovery, and high catalytic activity in a short reaction time, heterogeneous catalysts are always chosen over homogeneous and enzyme ones. Also, heterogeneous catalysts are easily adaptable for the process intensification process with the use of suitable reactor for product separation methods and used to develop large-scale production and commercialization [8]. Base catalysts like metal oxides, hydrotalcites, carbonates, and alkali and alkaline metal hydroxides are employed to transesterify glycerol with DMC. Although homogeneous base catalysts have remarkable activity and high turn over frequencies (TOF), their usage in glycerol transesterification is limited by the catalyst separation procedure and neutralising problems [9,10]. As they can be recovered and reused in reactions with high activity, the literature claims that this technique uses a lot of heterogeneous catalyst. By raising the reaction's yield and selectivity of necessary products, heterogeneous catalysts aid in the reaction's efficiency. A number of solid base catalysts, including KNO3/CaO [11], Li/ZnO [12], KF-modified hydroxyapatite [13], NaAlO2 [14], Li/ZrO2 [15], and ZnO/La2O3 [16], have been used to produce GlyC. However, these catalysts have some disadvantages. As a result, a novel method is being investigated to produce glycerol carbonate with increased activity and stability under moderate reaction conditions. K2CO3-MgO [17], LiNO3/Mg4AlO5.5 [18], Mg/Al/Zr [19] and Mg/Zr/Sr [20], CaO/ZrO2 [21], KF modified hydroxyapatite [13], Sr/Al2O3 [22] are only a few examples of the ample catalysts that have been used till date in the production of GlyC. In the temperature range of 75 to 100°C, each of these catalysts produced a glycerol conversion of 75 to 99%. Alkaline earth metal oxides have active basic sites and basic strengths in the following order: MgO > CaO > SrO > BaO. This is due to the action of CO2 adsorption. Though intriguing and challenging, it was possible to boost the catalytic activity, solidity, and basic strength of Magnesium oxide by mixing Mg with transition metal oxides (MnO2 and CuO). In this work, the effect of support metal as late transition metals like Mn, Fe, Co and Cu on Mg in increasing catalytic activity, stability of catalyst and towards glycerol conversion was studied. During this work, different catalysts were synthesized by coprecipitation method i.e. Mg/Mn, Mg/Fe, Mg/Co, Mg/Cu but, Mg only forms stable crystal with Mn and Cu and doesn't form stable catalyst with Fe and Co which was confirmed from XRD. Therefore, only Mn and Cu form stable catalyst with Mg whose further study was taken to check its catalytic activity towards synthesis of glycerol carbonate. Thus, we synthesized solid base catalysts made of magnesium, such as Mg/CuO and Mg/MnO2, and used them to transesterify glycerol. To increase the stability and catalytic activity of magnesium oxide, it was fascinating and difficult to mix magnesium with transition metal oxides like manganese oxide and copper oxide. In this study, the effect of transition metals like Mn and Cu on the activity of Mg metal in Gly transesterification was also examined. Here, a number of co-precipitation produced transition metal oxide (Cu and Mn) catalysts were produced for application in the production of GlyC. Individual reactions were monitored, and the effectiveness of these catalysts and the conversion rate of glycerol were both thoroughly investigated. Systematic analysis was done on the correlation between reactant species conversion, product yield percentage, selectivity, and acidic and basic characteristics. A variety of characterization methods, including XRD, TGA-DSC, FTIR, SEM, TEM and XPS spectra, were used to determine the physicochemical characteristics (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental procedures 2.1 Precursors and methodology All the analytical grade chemicals including, Mn(CH3COO)2.4H2O, Cu(NO3)2.9H2O, Mg(NO3)2.6H2O 99.0 wt.% DMC, 99.0% Glycerol, etc. were taken from Merck Limited, India. Ammonium hydroxide, Dimethyl carbonate, t-butanol, methanol was taken from S. D. fine chem Limited, New Delhi, India. 2.2 Synthesis of Mg modified transition metal catalysts The co-precipitation method was used to create magnesium and transition metal-based catalysts, such as Mg/CuO and Mg/MnO2 named as CMO and MMO respectively, within a constant pH range of 8–10. In the beginning, the necessary quantity of magnesium nitrate was liquefied in a certain quantity of double distilled water. A precise quantity of Mg(NO3)2.6H2O was taken and liquefied in double distilled water in a different beaker. At 40 ℃, both solutions were combined and stirred (Mg:Mn is 1:2). Ammonia solution (ammonium hydroxide) was added dropwise during the reaction process to maintain the pH between 8 and 10, as well as to create precipitation. The resultant mixture was agitated for further 5 h after the precipitate had formed in order to promote the precipitate phase's selective growth. After filtering, the product combination was repeatedly rinsed in hot water to eliminate any remaining contaminants. The solid sample was then calcined at 400 °C for 5 h in a muffle furnace after spending the previous day at 110 °C in an oven. The final step was to remove the finished product from furnace and crumpled it to obtain fine powder. The acquired material was kept in a safe place before being utilised to transesterify glycerol. Similar to this, glycerol transesterification catalysts like Mg modified CuO were created and tested. The lab scale reaction set up for one pot synthesis of glycerol carbonate is presented in supporting information S1. 2.3 Characterizations of Mg/CuO and Mg/MnO2 catalyst Several characterizations have been carried out in order to research the physicochemical characteristics of the produced catalyst. By performing TG-DSC study with a PerkinElmer Pvt. Ltd. STA (Simultaneous Thermal Analyzer) 6000 instrument, the % weight loss under increasing temperature was examined. A heating rate of 10°C min−1 was used to heat the catalyst between 50 and 700 °C. A KBr pellet was used to prepare the sample for FT-IR analysis using a Shimadzu IR affinity spectrophotometer, which looked at the molecular vibration of the functional groups found on the catalyst surface. The fingerprint region of 400 to 4000 cm−1 on the spectrum was recorded. By using an XRD analysis with CuKα as the radiation source, running at 45 kV, 112 mA current, a step size of 0.02, and a scan rate of 0.4/s, it was possible to determine whether crystal phases were present in the produced catalyst. Between 10 and 80°, the diffraction pattern was investigated. Using XPS spectroscopy, the manifestation of several elements and their oxidation states was investigated. For the purpose of standardising the binding energies of various elements, the C1s peak at 284.4 eV was chosen as a reference peak. By applying the BET-BJH analysis using the BELLSORP MAX II & BELCAT-II by MicrotracBEL Corp.br equipment, the surface area and pore volume of the produced catalyst were calculated. Using the Tecnai G2 20 TWIN instrument, SEM analysis was analysed by EVO Scanning electron microscope MA15/18 by CARL ZEISS MICROSCOPY LTD. HRTEM analysis was used to examine the internal structure of the produced catalyst and the Single Area Electron Diffraction pattern. By using titration values derived from a Hammett indicator titration, basic strength was determined. The many indicators used are phenolphthalein (H_ = 9.3), 2,4-dinitroaniline (H_ = 15.0), 4-nitroaniline (H_ = 18.4), and aniline (H_ = 27.0). Bromothymol blue (H_ = 7.2), 4-nitroaniline (H_ = 18.4), and aniline (H_ = 27.0) are among the others. 2.4 Evaluation of catalytic activity for GlyC synthesis In typical procedure of transesterification of Gly-to-GlyC using a direct reflux condensation, the activity of all the produced catalysts was evaluated. In two separate 200 ml round-bottom flasks, the reaction was conducted using 5.4 mmol of glycerol (5 g) and 16.2 mmol of DMC (14.6 g), respectively. The catalysts Mg/MnO2 and Mg/CuO were then added, with the weight percentages of each varying from 1 to 10 wt.% depending on the amount of Gly used. The mixtures were then heated to the ideal temperature for the ideal amount of time while being continuously stirred. In this typical work, transesterification was taking place in a round bottom flask connected with a reflux condenser. During the reaction at 90 ℃, the reactants whose boiling point is less than the set temperature is vaporized and condensed back into the reaction medium because of the reflux condenser. After the reaction, the methanol produced as a byproduct present in the reaction medium along with product is further evaporated by rotatory evaporator to get the pure product. Gas chromatography was used to track the progress of the reactions. Following the reaction method, the resultant mixtures were filtered to make it simple to separate the catalyst and continue the investigation in the following reaction process. The liquid mixture's leftover CH3OH was also parted using a rotary evaporator. Using GC (Agilent technology 7890B), the product was found using a capillary column HP-5 (30 m 0.32 mm 0.25 mm) with a flame ionization detector. For the quantification analysis, tert butanol was used as the internal standard. Using the following formulae, the conversion % and yield % of Gly and GlyC were determined. (1) Glycerol Conversion ( % ) = No of moles of glycerol reacted Total no of moles of glycerol taken × 100 (2) Selectivity ( % ) = No . of moles of desired product Total no of moles of all products × 100 (3) Yield ( % ) = % Glycerol conversion × % GlyC selectivity × 100 3 Result and discussions 3.1 Thermal stability: TGA-DSC study of synthesized catalysts The thermal stability of the CMO and MMO catalyst was evaluated using TGA and DSC, and the precursors' annealing temperature was established. Fig. 1 depicts, respectively, the temperature profiles of the precursors MMO and CMO. The TGA plot of uncalcined CMO was depicted in Fig. 1(a). In the TGA, two stages of mass decomposition with temperature rise has been observed. In the first stage of weight loss at 100-280 ℃ due to evaporation of surface adsorbed moisture left after drying in an oven. Further, second stage of weight loss which is observed from 300 to 700 ℃, after removal of crystal water molecules, disintegration of nitrates species presents in the precursor taken and the breaking and formation of bonds between Mg and O and Cu and O to form new bonds between Mg, Cu and O. This causes weight loss and results in formation of a crystal structure [23]. The DSC graph shows the process is endothermic in nature and the heat flow during first stage of weight loss is 472.3 J/g at 244.50 ℃ [23,24]. Fig. 1(b) clearly shows three areas of weight loss in the MMO sample. During TGA of MMO it was found that Mg with Mn shows only small amount of weight loss due to formation of stable crystal with Mn. At 400 ℃, Mn forms stable spinel crystal with Mg so it shows weight loss only before 400 ℃ due to removal of crystal adsorbed water. After 400 ℃, the crystal shows no weight loss and shows the formation of stable MgMn2O4 spinel structure which further confirmed by XRD. The weight loss observed i.e., 6.224%, which is caused by removal of lattice crystal moisture. The DSC plot shows that the process is exothermic in nature with the heat flow of -212.6 J/g. This result is consistent with the previous studies [25]. There has been a slight weight loss throughout the temperature range. The TG curve exhibits no weight loss further, indicating that the sample has stabilised. 3.2 XRD analysis The diffraction pattern of Fig. 2 shows the XRD diffraction pattern of CMO. The diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ equal to 35.88⁰, 39.00⁰, 49.00⁰, 58.57⁰ shows the formation of MgCu4O5 matched with JCPDS card no. 470681. The remaining peaks at 2θ values 32.76⁰, 61.63⁰, 65.99⁰, 65.99⁰, 72.00⁰, 75.55⁰ shows the existence of CuO in the crystal lattice matched with JCPDS card no. 010720629. This confirms the formation of mixed phase of MgCu4O5 and CuO in CMO catalyst [24]. On the other hand, Fig. 2 shows the XRD pattern of MMO. It is clearly visible in the diffraction patterns consisting of miller indices at (101), (200), (103), (211), (202), (220), (303), (215), (116), and (323) corresponds to 2θ = 18°, 29°, 32°, 36°, 37°, and 44°, 56°, 61°, 64°, and 66°, which resembles to MgMn2O4 spinel crystal structure, 141/amd space group, the crystal system is tetragonal with lattice parameters a = b = 5.7280, c= 9.3460. all angles α = β = γ = 90⁰ [25,26] consistent with JCPDS file no. 0230392, respectively. The high degree of crystallinity of the materials is indicated by the strong peak in XRD patterns. The structure of MgMn2O4 is similar to the spinel tetragonal structure, in which Mg2+ and Mn3+ /4+ ions occupy tetrahedral and octahedral positions, respectively. 3.3 XPS analysis Fig. 3 (A) and (B) show the results of an XPS examination used to determine the oxidation states and atomic energy levels of the various elements included in the produced catalysts MMO and CMO. The XPS characteristic peaks were calibrated using the adventitious C1s peak as the benchmark, which displays binding energy of 284.68 eV. The MMO catalyst's XPS spectra are shown in Fig. 3(A), and they show that Mg, Mn, and O are present in the catalyst. A distinctive peak at 1303.79 eV in the Mg spectra indicates the presence of Mg metal in the 1s shell with a +2 oxidation state. The existence of Mn in the +4 and +3 oxidation states may be seen in the Mn spectra, where the Mn 2p peak appears with binding energies of 641.30 eV and 652.82 eV, respectively. Mn-O and Mg-O metal-oxygen bonding are responsible for the distinctive peaks in the O1s spectra at 530.92 eV and 529.38 eV, respectively [27–29]. Fig. 3(B) displays the XPS spectra of the CMO catalyst, confirming the presence of Mg, Cu, and O in the CMO catalyst. The distinctive peak in the magnesium spectra at 1303.79 eV confirms the presence of Mg metal in a 1s shell with a +2 oxidation state. The Cu XPS spectrum shows Cu in 2p shell having binding energies 933.55 eV signifies Cu 2p3/2, the decovoluted peaks at binding energies 941.41, 943.53 eV signifies presence of strong Cu+2 satellite peak. Also, the peaks at 953.52, 962.23 eV shows Cu2p1/2 depicts the presence of strong Cu+2 satellite peak. The O1s spectra shows the peaks at 529.43, 531.39 eV confirms the metal oxygen bonding [30–32]. In MMO, Mn exists in +4 oxidation state and in CMO, Cu exists in +2 oxidation state. Smaller size of Mn and higher oxidation state increases its electrophilicity than Cu which facilitates the attack of glyceroxide ion of glycerol on carbonyl carbon of DMC hence increases the glycerol conversion in MMO than in case of CMO. The outcomes are in agreement with the Thermo Fisher XPS database and NIST XPS database. The oxidation states of the existing elements display confirmation with the XRD results. 3.4 FTIR spectra and SEM analysis Fig. 4 shows the FT-IR patterns of MMO and CMO respectively. The peaks appeared between 500 and 650 cm−1 denotes the metal – metal and metal oxygen bonding. The two distinct peaks at 536 cm−1 and 634 cm−1 corresponds to Mn-O and Mg-O vibrations respectively [33,23,24]. In CMO, the vibration band at 524.48 and 590.37 cm−1 corresponds to Mg-O and Cu-O. The small peak around 1600 cm−1 depicts the bending vibration of adsorbed water molecules in the crystal lattice. Further, the peak appeared at 3400 to 3700 cm−1 signifies the stretching vibration of water and hydroxyl molecules present in the crystal lattice due to absorption of water [34,35]. The surface morphology of MMO and CMO was observed by SEM technique in Fig. 5(a) and (b) respectivily. It was observed that the SEM micrographs of MMO demonstrates uniform spheroid like grains of irregular sizes in the complete system. No agglomeration was observed demonstrates the successful incorporation of MgO into MnO2 crystal to form spinel having strong surface synergism. In case of CMO, the grains are of rectangular morphology and few are also having spheroidal morphology of irregular size. Some agglomerations are observed which signifies non-uniform assimilation of MgO on CuO crystal. The results are consistent with the TEM results. 3.5 TEM-EDAX analysis Fig. 6 (A) and (B) displayed the TEM micrographs of MMO and CMO respectively. The TEM micrographs of MMO were studied under 100 nm resolution. The micrographs show the particles are of irregular spheroidal morphology. Two types of particles were seen which collaborates to the Mn and Mg particles adsorbed one over the other. The selected area diffraction pattern (SAED) shows clearly defined electron diffraction spots which substantiate the crystalline nature of the MMO spinel. The interplanar spacing between crystal planes were calculated by high resolution TEM micrograph. The interplanar d spacing comes out to be 1.87 Ao which is consistent with crystal plane (301). The EDAX pattern confirms the presence of different elements in their respective atomic % which is Mg in 18.92%, Mn in 47.48% and O in 33.61 [36,37]. On the other hand, the TEM micrograph of CMO shows that particles are of spherical as well as rectangular morphology stick to each other. The selected area diffraction pattern (SAED) depicts electron diffraction spots clearly visible evident the crystalline nature of CMO catalyst. The EDAX pattern confirms the presence of different elements in their respective atomic % which is Mg in 17.82%, Cu in 38.56% and O in 43.62% [38] . The presence of different elements detected by EDAX analysis in TEM-EDAX is similar to that detected by XRD. Also, the proportion of different elements is nearly consistent to that in spinel MgMn2O4. The results are in consistent with the XRD results. 3.6 Surface area analysis The surface area of the synthesized catalysts was determined by BET adsorption desorption isotherm and the pore volume and pore diameter was determined by BJH plot depicted in Fig. 7 . Both isotherm plots follow type IV H1 type hysteresis loop shown in Fig. 7(a) and (c). The signifies that the catalyst is having mesoporous textural properties (pore size lies between 2 and 50 nm). The single point surface area and total pore volume of CMO are 2.64 m2g and 0.042 cm3/g and that of MMO are 14.94 m2/g and 0.224 cm3/g. This implies that the surface increases exponentially when Mg is doped with MnO2. The pore diameter determined by BJH analysis of CMO and MMO are 64.25 nm and 58.65 nm respectively (Fig. 7(b) & (d)). It was anticipated that the formation of spinal increases the surface area of the catalyst which results in good catalytic activity of the synthesized catalyst MMO towards high conversion of glycerol to glycerol carbonate in high yield%. [39]. 3.7 Basicity It is important to carry out investigation on the basic strength and basicity of designed catalyst because a heterogeneous catalyst's basicity play a vital role in the trans esterification of glycerol. As the active basic site firstly abstracts the proton from glycerol molecule to form glyceroxide ion and proceeds the reaction. Therefore, active basic site and its basic strength plays an important role in transesterification of glycerol. In this study, basic strength was investigated using a simple Hammett indicator titration method, and the outcomes are displayed in Table 1 . The indicator solution dilute with CH3OH was combined with 25 mg of catalyst, and the mixture was left to equilibrate for two hours. The indicator solution's color changed after some time, indicating that the catalyst (MMO and CMO) is a stronger base than the indicator. The total basicity of the generated catalysts (MMO and CMO) was quantitatively assessed using the Hammett indicator benzene carboxylic acid titration technique. Pure Mg(NO3)2 have a fairly weak medium basic catalyst site with a H_ value ranging from 9.8 to 15.0. The color of bromothymol blue was not altered by its acidic parent compounds, Cu (NO3)3 and Mn (NO3)3, in a manner similar to that. To make the salts more fundamentally strong, MgO was added to all of them. When MgO was added, it was found that the catalysts' basic strengths decreased from 15.5 to 18.4. The three catalysts showed equivalent basic strengths, but MgMn2O4 (MMO) had the most basic sites (total basicity in millimole /g) compared to MgCu4O5 (CMO) as given in Table 1. As transesterification followed a base-catalysed process, MMO's most basic site improved the conversion of glycerol [40]. 3.8 Gas chromatography analysis of synthesized product glycerol carbonate A GC analysis was used to quantify the produced substance. Tert-butanol is utilised for the analysis as an internal standard solvent when preparing the sample. Glycerol carbonate's retention time was determined to be 16.5 min after the analysis (Fig. S2). This demonstrates how glycerol completely transforms into glycerol carbonate. The peak of the unconverted glycerol can be seen on the typical gas chromatogram curve of glycerol carbonate, which has a retention time range of 14.90–16.50 min. 3.9 Optimization of reaction parameters 3.9.1 Reaction temperature Fig. 8(a) was optimised and made clear to show that temperature is one of the key elements in the transesterification of Gly. The highest GlyC output of 94% and the highest glycerol conversion of 97% were found to occur at 90 °C. Glycerol conversion did not significantly increase above 90 °C, indicating a high-temperature decarboxylation event that resulted in glycidol, which was then polymerized by ring-opening. The steady decrease in glycerol carbonate selectivity that is seen as temperature rises is attributable to the rise in glycidol selectivity. According to the literature, glycerol carbonate's decarbonylation, which is more frequent at higher temperatures, is the primary cause of cumulative glycidol selectivity. Glycidol and diglycerol carbonate are more likely to develop when reaction temperatures are raised. A higher reaction temperature can cause glycerol carbonate to break down into glycidol. Consequently, a reaction temperature of 90 ℃ is established as the ideal temperature [44,45]. High temperatures also accelerated unwanted processes including the dehydrogenation and condensation of byproduct CH3OH, which reduced the activity of the catalyst in the % conversion of glycerol. 3.9.2 Reaction time Fig. 8(b) presents studies on the impact of reaction duration during glycerol transesterification. The reaction had the maximum conversion, 97%, when the response time was prolonged from 25 to 75 min. Glycerol conversion increased from 52 to 97% at 75 min. The production and conversion rates of glycerol carbonate and glycerol decreased significantly as the time was extended past 75 min, indicating that glycidol had likely been produced. Additionally, the glycerol carbonate selectivity declines as reaction time increases. This is so because MnO2's acidic sites encourage the decarboxylation of glycerol carbonate to produce glycidol. The concentration of glycerol lowers as the reaction proceeds, forming glycerol carbonate, which produces glycidol. This kind of inconsistency in GlyC yield and glycerol conversion may have resulted from the process's short 75 min time to equilibrium [46]. Depending on the purity of the final product, it was believed that 75 min was the best reaction time for transesterification of glycerol using this method. 3.9.3 Gly to DMC molar ratio Fig. 8(c) illustrates the major influence of the reactant molar ratio on the transesterification reaction. With a change in the reactants' molar ratio from 1:1 to 4:1, it was discovered that Gly % conversion increased from 56 to 97% and its % yield from 48 to 94%. It's possible that the immiscibility of hydrophilic Gly and hydrophobic DMC at high concentrations, or the solubility effect, is what's causing the gradual fall in glycerol conversion when the DMC to Gly ratio grows beyond 4:1. Another feature that made it challenging to convert glycerol at high DMC:Gly molar ratios was the extremely low concentration of glycerol, which caused the rate of reaction to slow down [47]. 3.9.4 Catalyst loading The analysis into the impact of the catalyst amount taken in the Gly transesterification process is shown in Fig. 8(d), which shows the findings. The percentage of Gly that was converted increased continuously from 62% to 97% with an increase in catalyst amount up to 5 wt% of the Gly used in the reaction process. This increase in Gly conversion rate may be due to an increase in the overall number of basic sites for catalysts. Gly conversion was unaffected by additional catalyst additions exceeding 5 wt%, proving that the catalyst is resistant to the development of solid-liquid emulsions. Another factor to take into account is the possibility of pore obstruction and a lack of active sites as a result of particle aggregation at larger catalyst masses [48]. 3.10 Reusability of catalyst As illustrated in Fig. 9 (a), an investigation into the stability, activity, and reuse of synthesised catalyst also considered the advantages for the economy and the environment. After six cycles of transesterifying glycerol, it was found that the catalyst held up well. The reusability of the catalyst was tested using leaching tests utilising a hot filteration method. Batch studies were routinely carried out in this process. Each reaction was followed by a thorough cleaning with methanol before the catalysts were dried in an oven. Fig. 9(a) displayed the yield % of GlyC and the conversion percentage of glycerol from the previous catalyst that had been regenerated. The results demonstrate that the catalyst is highly efficient and may be reused for up to six runs without significantly losing activity. The ordered crystallite structure of the catalyst's phase, which aids in stabilising the Mg2+ and Mn4+ as shown XRD and TEM study shown in Fig. 9(b) & (c), is believed to be responsible for the phenomena of stability of the catalyst up to the sixth runs [49–51]. From XRD and TEM, it is clear that the structure of the catalyst is not deformed after reusability which is responsible for its higher stability and high catalytic activity up to six reaction cycles. After reusability, no catalyst leaching is found in synthesized product which confirmed by performing FTIR analysis of the synthesized glycerol carbonate (Fig. 9(d)). The absorption band around 1760 to 1790 cm−1 indicates the carbonyl stretching frequency of carbonyl group present in glycerol carbonate. The broad band indicates the O-H stretching band. None of the metal oxide peaks of MMO vibrations were observed. The graph shows only glycerol carbonate vibration matched with previous reported literature [52]. The loss in the activity after sixth run is validated by hot filtration test. Surface wear is the cause of the decline in catalytic activity. Some of the active ingredients in the solution are lost in the friction between the magnetic stirrer and the reactor's bottom as fine powder, which is then further filtered out. The high volume reactor can be used to replace the magnetic stirrer with a mechanical agitator in order to prevent surface wearing. 3.11 Detailed study of reaction mechanism in transesterification of glycerol During the mechanism, initially the Mg2+ Lewis basic site of the synthesised MMO catalyst first abstracts the main hydroxyl group of glycerol; at the same time, the Mn4+ Lewis acidic site activates the carbonyl carbon of DMC. The produced glyceroxide anion is then subjected to nucleophilic addition with activated DMC to produce hydroxyl alkyl carbonate, with the by-product of methanol being eliminated. The unstable intermediate is cyclised to produce cyclic GlyC, which renews the MMO catalyst. The fundamental site of the catalyst's absorption of H+ from glycerol is MgO site while MnO2 support acts in increasing electrophilicity of carbonyl C of DMC. The more negatively charged glyceroxide anion may be caused by a catalyst with a higher basic strength. This lowers the free energy [41–43]. The proposed MgMn2O4 with the highest basicity supports glycerol conversion with the maximum glycerol carbonate yield of 94% [52,62]. 3.12 Comparative study of synthesized catalyst with previous reported catalysts Different literature has been reported several heterogeneous catalyst undergoing transesterification reaction of glycerol. Table 2 shows the list of several catalysts operated for glycerol carbonate synthesis at different reaction conditions. Catalysts like MgO/ZrO2 catalyst provided a very good conversion of glycerol (96%) at an expense of a prolonged reaction time (150 min), although the yield percentage towards GlyC is quite low, 88%. Li impregnated ZnO catalyst also shown efficient glycerol conversion, although the catalyst's main limitations are its delayed reaction time and high reaction temperature [53]. Another catalyst, NaAlO2 [54], with a Glycerol template had the highest selectivity for GlyC (100%) but required a long reaction time. Similar to many other catalysts, Li/Mg4AlO [55], Mg/La2O3 [56], KF/La-Zr [57], Li/ZrO2 [58], Zn/La [59], and Ca/La [60] have a variety of drawbacks including a long reaction time, high reaction temperature, poor reusability, very low conversion, yield, and selectivity, high DMC to glycerol molar ratios, and more. In order to improve catalytic activity in the transesterification of glycerol with minimal reaction parameters (less time consumption, low temperature, low DMC:Glycerol molar ratio, low catalyst loading%), high recyclability, and also to overcome all the drawbacks in the transesterification reaction of glycerol, we designed and investigated the properties of a new heterogeneous MMO catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this study, glycerol waste from the biodiesel industry was used to create glycerol carbonate via a greener process known as transesterification. We were able to successfully synthesise CMO and MMO and investigate their catalytic activity during the transesterification of glycerol. For the transesterification reaction, a comparison between catalysts-like CMO and MMO was done. The full development of the CMO and MMO framework was shown by sophisticated techniques as XRD, SEM, TEM-EDX, XPS, FTIR and TGA-DSC. All of the characterizations indicated that MMO has better physicochemical properties than CMO catalyst. All these characteristics of MMO were very helpful for converting glycerol into glycerol carbonate. The catalytic activity and the stability of the active basic site (Mg-O) are both increased by the higher oxidation state of Mn, or +4, in the bifunctional MgMn2O4 spinel. This is another significant factor for the better conversion of glycerol utilising MMO is its higher basicity. This increases the catalytic activity of MMO for glycerol transesterification in comparison to CMO. This signifies the role of support metal in enhancing the activity of catalyst. In order to attain optimal conditions and a higher yield of glycerol carbonate, several reaction parameters were improved. The maximum conversion and yield obtained are 97% and 94% respectively. The optimized reaction condition for maximum conversion and yield are 90 ℃ reaction temperature, 1:4 glycerol to DMC molar ratio, 5 wt.% of catalyst dose and within 75 min of reaction time produces maximum conversion of glycerol-to-glycerol carbonate. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol carbonate (GlyC) is desirable compound among numerous value-added products produced from surplus waste glycerol coming from biodiesel industry. Because of its excellent characteristics properties, applications and high cost, it can contribute to economize the biodiesel production cost. In this work, the research on the impact of support on the catalytic activity towards the synthesis of GlyC have been developed. For this purpose, co-precipitation was used to create Mg and transition metals like Cu and Mn based catalysts, which were then used in the transesterification of glycerol (Gly). Comparative research on the catalytic abilities of MgMn2O4 (MMO) and MgCu4O5 (CMO) were conducted. Among CMO and MMO catalysts, MMO achieved the maximum glycerol conversion of 97%, with 94% GlyC yield, while CMO only offered 83% glycerol conversion with 71% GlyC yield. The 4:1 DMC to Gly molar ratio, 90°C reaction temperature, 75 min reaction time, and 5% catalyst loading were the optimal reaction parameters that were most effective for the synthesis of GlyC utilizing MMO catalyst. MMO was more effective than CMO at synthesizing GlyC because it has a strong basic site. With stability through the sixth cycle, the catalyst has a great potential. An industrial application of the catalyst for large scale is possible. The impact of support transition metal on catalytic activity is established by this study.
coredata.dc:title: Studies on role of support metal in glycerol conversion to glycerol carbonate through Mg/MnO2 and Mg/CuO heterogeneous catalyst
